title: AB 1685
content: The State of California enacts the following. Section 43016 of the Health and Safety Code in California is amended. Section 43016 of the Health and Safety Code in California establishes civil penalties for violations of emission control laws, with a maximum penalty of $37,500 per violation. Manufacturers or distributors may also be required to pay penalties and ensure compliance with regulations to continue selling regulated products in the state. The state board adjusts maximum penalties for inflation based on the California Consumer Price Index, exempt from the Administrative Procedure Act. Penalties collected are deposited in the Air Pollution Control Fund. Section 43151 prohibits selling, importing, or using uncertified motor vehicles in California. The article does not apply to a vehicle acquired to replace a damaged or stolen vehicle, or transferred by inheritance or court decree. This chapter does not apply to a motor vehicle with a certificate of conformity under the federal Clean Air Act, originally registered in another state by a resident who moves to this state and provides proof of previous registration. This provision takes effect 180 days after regulations are adopted for certifying new direct import vehicles. Section 43154 of the Health and Safety Code is amended to impose civil penalties for violations of emission control laws. The penalty for individuals can be up to $37,500 per violation, while dealers may face penalties of up to $10,000 per violation. Compliance with emission control laws may be required for manufacturers and distributors to continue selling vehicles in the state. A dealer violating emission control laws may face a civil penalty of up to $10,000 per violation, with adjustments for inflation based on the California Consumer Price Index. Any action to recover a penalty under this section shall be brought in the name of the people of the State of California in the superior court of the county where the violation occurred, by the Attorney General or other designated officials, with penalties deposited in the Air Pollution Control Fund. Section 43211 of the Health and Safety Code in California states that new motor vehicles must meet emission standards set by the state board. Manufacturers who sell vehicles that fail to meet these standards may face civil penalties. The penalty for failure to meet zero-emission vehicle credit requirements is capped at $5,000 per credit. The state board adjusts maximum penalties for inflation based on the California Consumer Price Index, exempt from the Administrative Procedure Act. Penalties recovered are deposited into the General Fund. Section 43212 of the Health and Safety Code is amended. Any penalty recovered under this section will go into the General Fund. Manufacturers or distributors not meeting emission standards may face a civil penalty of up to $37,500 per non-compliant vehicle sold in California. The executive officer of the state board may require payment of penalties and compliance with emission laws as conditions for further vehicle sales in the state. The state board can adjust the maximum penalty for inflation based on the California Consumer Price Index. Any penalty collected will be deposited into the Air Pollution Control Fund. The state board has the authority to order a manufacturer to bring their vehicles into compliance with certified emissions configurations, with compliance being a condition for continued vehicle sales in the state.
